direct.translation[0].definitions[0].def: done without any other people, actions, processes etc coming between
direct.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Experienced users have direct access to the main data files.
I’m not in direct contact with them.
Few policy-makers have had direct experience of business.
Educational level has a sizeable direct effect on income.
There is a direct link between poverty and ill-health.
The decision to close the hospital is a direct result of Government health policy.
direct.translation[0].definitions[1].def: going straight from one place to another without stopping or changing direction
direct.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Which is the most direct route to London?
a direct flight to New York
direct.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Weight increases in direct proportion to mass.
For Lawrence, in direct contrast to Adam, everything seemed to come so easily.
a direct quote (=exact words) from the book
direct.translation[0].definitions[3].def: saying exactly what you mean in an honest clear way
direct.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Women often feel men are too direct and not sympathetic enough.
Now, let me ask you a direct question, and I expect a direct answer.
direct.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Very few people have direct access to the president.
The disease is only spread by direct contact between people.
The campaign makes a direct link between global warming and the consumption of energy in the home.
We think having a direct relationship with customers is very important.
Our organization’s work has a direct impact upon children’s lives in this country.
Many illnesses here are a direct consequence of bad diet.
People learn best through direct experience.
There is no direct evidence that this causes any harm.
The state has direct control over certain industries.
direct.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to aim something in a particular direction or at a particular person, group etc
direct.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I’d like to direct your attention to paragraph four.
I want to direct my efforts more towards my own projects.
The machine directs an X-ray beam at the patient’s body.
The new route directs lorries away from the town centre.
direct.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to be in charge of something or control it
direct.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Mr Turner was directing the investigation from a very early stage.
The choir was directed by Sir David Willcocks.
direct.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to give the actors in a play, film, or television programme instructions about what they should do
direct.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The play was directed by Frank Hauser.
direct.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to tell someone how to get to a place
direct.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Could you direct me to Trafalgar Square, please?
direct.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to tell someone what they should do
direct.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: The judge directed the jury to find Mr Baggs not guilty.
He directed that his body should be buried in Upton.
direct.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Can we fly direct to Chicago, or do we stop in Salt Lake City first?
direct.translation[2].definitions[1].def: without dealing with anyone else first
direct.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Esther decided to contact the manager direct.
It is usually cheaper to buy the goods direct from the wholesaler.
